Conservative.tenets: Emphasizes tradition, social stability, limited government in markets, strong national defense, respect for institutions and norms.
Conservative.history: Roots in reaction to radical change in 18th–19th century Europe. In U.S., grew via 20th-century classical liberal economic ideas mixed with social conservatism.
Conservative.popularity: Strong in U.S. Republican base; conservative parties and media have influence globally, though levels vary.
Conservative.current_figures: Examples: Ronald Reagan (historical), Margaret Thatcher (UK), more recently prominent voices in GOP and conservative media.

philosophers.name: Edmund Burke
philosophers.works: Reflections on the Revolution in France (1790)
philosophers.notes: Prudence, respect for tradition, caution toward radical change

philosophers.name: Michael Oakeshott
philosophers.notes: Skepticism of grand design and rationalist planning

Progressive.tenets: Advocates equity, strong regulatory state, social justice, public goods, expansion of civil rights, active government role.
Progressive.history: U.S. Progressive Era (1890s–1920s), later civil rights era, modern progressive movements, left reform traditions globally.
Progressive.popularity: Core of progressive wings within left-of-center parties (e.g. Democrats in U.S.); parallels in social-democratic/green parties globally.
Progressive.current_figures: Examples: Franklin D. Roosevelt, Lyndon Johnson (historical); modern progressive U.S. politicians, movements around climate policy, social welfare.

philosophers.name: John Dewey
philosophers.notes: Pragmatic democracy, education as social tool

Libertarian.tenets: Maximum individual liberty, minimal government, free markets, strong property rights, skepticism of coercion or paternalism.
Libertarian.history: Derives from classical liberalism, with resurgence in 20th century via Austrian economics, public choice, civil-liberties movements.
Libertarian.popularity: Smaller but notable niche in U.S. (Libertarian Party, think tanks), present in policy debates and international free-market networks.
Libertarian.current_figures: Examples: Friedrich Hayek, Milton Friedman (historical); current voices in think tanks, digital media, academia.

Keynesian.tenets: Active macroeconomic policy, counter-cyclical fiscal and monetary intervention, pursuit of full employment and stability.
Keynesian.history: Originates with John Maynard Keynes in 1930s; dominant mid-20th century; evolved to New Keynesian frameworks.
Keynesian.popularity: Influential in governmental economics, central banks, especially in volatile periods; mainstream in many countries’ economic policy toolkits.
Keynesian.current_figures: John Maynard Keynes (historical); modern economists in central banking, academia, ministerial advisors.

philosophers.name: John Maynard Keynes
philosophers.works: The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money (1936)
philosophers.notes: Effective demand, liquidity preference, fiscal policy

philosophers.name: James Tobin
philosophers.notes: Portfolio selection, stabilization, bridging Keynesian and financial markets
